pros: Amazing benefits and professional development.
cons: There were no cons to working at ONE.

review_title: Inspiring work//organisational culture leaves room for improvement
pros: Inspiring mission to end poverty and preventable disease, amazing CEO, and great flexibility. Great opportunity to drive meaningful change, especially because the organisation has built a strong and credible reputation, and is a leader in the development sector.
cons: Company culture and priorities heavily dominated by US-centric perspectives. There is a lot of room for improvement in strengthening DEI in organisational culture, which doesn't seem to be a priority for leadership. It would be good to see the organisation live out its values for 'big ideas' and focus on addressing systemic issues and building transformational change.

review_title: Good place but opaque eligibility criteria for promotion or bonus
pros: Brilliant minds to work with. Flexible working arrangement.
cons: What must be done in order to qualify for a promotion or incentive is unclear. Staff members receive unequal remuneration despite being on the same level. Heavy on top while career path for junior staff is not clear.

pros: Great people, excellent benefits, and flexible hours
cons: It is difficult to grow in your role and upward nobility is based strictly on seniority.

review_title: Great mission but difficult for juniors to progress
pros: Excellent work life balanc e Good mission Great colleagues Interesting work
cons: Lack of transparency around progression Uncompetitive salary Lack of action behind D&I commitment

review_title: Top heavy and lacking any real innovation
pros: Some good campaign areas. Opportunity for international travel.
cons: Theme of micromanagement. Culture issues including micro aggressions. Vast pay disparity between and within grades. Incredibly top heavy with over recruitment and promotion to deputy director and director, senior director etc. Poor work/life balance with extra hours an expectation. Teams understaffed at grades below senior manager which contributes to poor work/life balance. Mostly repetitive campaign ideas that lack true innovation and impact due to high risk aversion.

pros: It’s a multi cultural working space with so many brilliant professionals to learn from
cons: It’s hard to find fault during my time there . It was everything I expected

pros: Great team ethos, Focused , intentional diversity, Commitment to organisational goals
cons: Uncertainty around internal career path, Salary ,

pros: My time at ONE was filled with lots of exciting and engaging opportunities. I was given a lot of creative projects to lead and over time I felt like I was seen as a leader for the organization. It wasn't always easy but being able to work on policy and campaigning on issues that are important to me was very meaningful. ONE has a lot of bright and talented people moving the mission forward.
cons: Working on issues that are so dependent on what's happening on Capitol Hill can be difficult but I think the ONE team and the ONE activists find a way to cut through the noise. ONE doesn't have a lot of opportunities for upward mobility. It's an organization that loses a lot of staff because they aren't willing to promote or don't have the resources to do so.

pros:
Mission driven organization
Collaboration to solve the world's largest and most systemic problems
Many people working at ONE are friendly and easy to work with
Nice, centrally located office
Decent benefits package and paid leave policies
cons:
Constantly trying to accomplish too many goals all at the same time
Significant pressure to deliver results, but non-specific about what results are
Culture that expects perfection, which doesn't leave room for learning
Compensation is above some other non-profits, but still low for expectations

pros:
- Smart, passionate, and compassionate colleagues
- Kind and considerate leadership that places employees' wellbeing first 
- Get to work with colleagues from diverse cultures around the world 
- Get to work on an important mission 
- Relatively horizontal organization - good ideas matter more than the title of the person who comes up with them
- Badass yet fun and down-to-earth CEO
- Respect for work-life balance
cons: - slightly risk averse in it approach

pros: Diverse, Multicultural environment, Awesome colleagues
cons: Lack of room to grow

pros: Good working condition, flexible environment, fast paced
cons: No cons. Well done to the management

review_title: Great place to work and grow.
pros: Committed to DEI. Great work with volunteers. Good benefits. Work life balance.
cons: Sometimes tight but reasonable deadlines.

job_title: Digital Campaign Manager in Abuja, Federal Capital Territory
pros: Great place to work particularly in Nigeria
cons: Limited opportunity to move within the ranks internally

pros: Supportive, great staff, encouraging, deliver great campaigns
cons: Experience varies across teams in terms of support and opportunities

pros: International, high speed environment and interesting professional challenges.
cons: Low work-life balance; managerial issues

review_title: Org on a Mission, but be prepared to work
pros:

International team
Resourced
Time off

NGO salaries

review_title: Great company thats mission driven. Could improve on work life balance
pros: teamwork, constant innovation, mission driven and passionate
cons: could definitely improve work life balance

job_title: Officer in Abuja, Federal Capital Territory
pros:
Competitive pay
Fast-paced environment
Healthy work environment
cons: I can't think of any for now

job_title: Senior Human Resources Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Great benefits (health benefits are wonderful, opportunities for learning and development)
cons:
Where should I begin...

There is great turn over and I believe it begins with management. People in management are really disconnected and have a great sense of entitlement. Upper Management doesn't listen and has a fear of transparency. As an employee, I felt undervalued, unheard, disrespected and micromanaged at times. Despite several years of experience I was never allowed to shine because I wasn't on the "right" team or in the "right" department. The front office and in a world of its own and the closer you are to the CEO the more power you have. 

The organization does great work and has a great external representation, but internally they don't value their employees, their skills, and what they bring to the table in terms of experience and knowledge. They won't allow for an employee survey because they don't want to acknowledge there is an issue, therefore, nothing needs to be addressed or fixed. They have been through a whole entire HR team because they don't view HR as a business partner and stakeholder. This is the only organization I have ever worked for where HR is voiceless and has no power to work with or on behalf of the employees even as a mediator.

pros: Fosters a great office community
cons: Little room to grow within the company

review_title: Learned a lot, met great people, aimed high.
pros: Fast pace of work and can-do attitude of many people there
cons: Getting a bit too big as an organisation to be nimble

review_title: Great mission, lack of communication internally
pros: Great people to work with depending what team you are on. Good benefits, beautiful office space, lots of fun office activities, good work/life balance. Best pro is the work ONE has accomplished and is continuing to do to end extreme poverty.
cons: Very little diversity when it comes to employees and who is running the show. ONE as a whole doesn't seem to be value people with different perspectives and backgrounds. There are people who have been at ONE for years that seem to have forgotten that there are people working at ONE outside of their inner circle or the front office that matter. Hard for promotion and movement. Lack of communication and collaboration between teams. Only real power if connected to someone at the C suite level.

pros: This was a great start for me in my early career. My colleagues at ONE are committed to the advocacy mission and know how to have fun and energize the work environment.
cons: Very high turnover and dysfunctional HR practices. Very little mobility once you get a job there causing many to leave in a year or two and seek other opportunities for growth.  While I love most my colleagues most are not good managers and could use formal training on this.

pros: Fairly easy work, working remotely
cons: Stagnant wages, disinterest in improving, more hand-wringing and indecision than action

review_title: ONE has a terrific reputation in the development world and needs to make a lot of internal improvements.
pros: Many creative and smart people.  Very successful in what they do.  High profile and influential.
cons: Innovation is often suffocated through bureaucracy.  White men run an organization dedicated to helping Africans, with an emphasis on women.  The executives have little to do with the overall staff and do not understand how their lack of management results in the loss of good people.  They like to attribute staff loss to "having a good farm team."

review_title: Seemed like it was getting better, but it's not
pros: Some of the best people I've ever worked with have been here at ONE. Everyone is smart, knowns their stuff and truly cares about the cause.
cons:
Staff isn't trusted with decision making.  
Little to no upward mobility.
Not a lot of diversity in most teams or Sr Management.

review_title: Great mission, quality staff, could be implemented better
pros:
-Great mission, to end extreme poverty
-Org is well-respected in advocacy world and has great access to important stakeholders
-Good work/life balance
-Friendly and fun staff
-Great benefits (vacation time, health insurance, 401K match, etc.)
cons:
-Leadership is indecisive
-Not committed to long-term professional development, difficult to move up
-For some positions, work/life balance is challenging
-Not serious about impact measurement

pros: Leading advocacy organization in the international development arena. Very successful at what they do with good opportunities for growth at certain levels of the organization (particularly low to mid-level).
cons: Perspectives of women not typically taken into account, internally and for external advocacy work, particularly due to few women being in the executive management team and Board of Directors.

review_title: Lots of great stuff happening here
pros: There is a lot of energy and collaboration.  The organization is highly respected
cons: creativity is rewarded only on senior level and only a select few.  there is a lot of disorganization that leads to projects being unnecessarily stressful.

review_title: Poor management practices, inability to hold on to talent
pros: Great energy around the office, good pay, perks, and benefits relative to others in industry. People are generally warm and welcoming to newcomers.
cons:
Management style is inconsistent. There are some terribly discouraging micro-managers who are extremely difficult to work with, while there are also some excellent ones who have faith in the - sometimes over- qualified - people they've hired to take initiative and do their job well. It's really a matter of luck who you end up with, and with turnover being so high there is no telling who you may have to work with in the future out of this mix of people. Commitment to working hard (including evenings and weekends) - that is, quantity of work - is rewarded well above quality of work. Despite constant discussion over improving work-life balance, very few managers help protect their juniors' personal time, partly because the people who are promoted to management are usually those that have shown little inclination to protect their own personal time.  This attitude  leads to a lot of the more talented people leaving after a year or two for more flexible working environments and opportunity for growth. Meanwhile, reinventing the wheel on earlier work and the inability to retain institutional knowledge creates a frustrating level of inefficiency and a lack of ownership in terms of the output produced. 

The organisation is also very personality-driven in terms of upper management, and organisational mission and implementation of that mission is ever-shifting as a result. This leads to a general lack of professionalism and consistency at every level as leadership styles and accompanying expectations keep changing, which the organisation is no longer young enough to justify still experiencing.

pros: Great benefits, non-profit atmosphere.  Close to Metro.
cons: Approach to the mission has become angry, one- sided and overtly aggressive, rather than the positive,  inclusive and very effective approach used in the past.  This shift in attitude will not serve the mission well and will render the organization less effective, if not ineffective.

pros: Very respectable org and works collaboratively with many other ngos. Great benefits and pay is moderately good compared to other ngos.
cons: Bad leadership. High turnover rate. Long work hours that usually extend into weekend.

pros: Excellent colleagues; relevant and meaningful work; creative pieces elevate campaigns; opportunity to work on different projects; nice to be part of global office structure
cons: Not always a clear path to advancement; very regular turnover; work pace environment is incredibly fast paced, can be easy to burn out;

review_title: Strong mission, typical nonprofit internal challenges
pros: Attracts staff very enthusiastic about the mission of ONE's work, global nonprofit with deep advocacy experience
cons: Several years ago (prior to current CEO), there was a lack of diversity amongst executive team and few outlets for staff feedback to management.

pros: Good culture, mission of the organization is important, feel like you are doing good work, growing internationally which expands the voice of the organization and adds new viewpoints.
cons: High turnover among leadership, lack of transparency from the top down

pros: pros:good work-life balance at the company, opportunity to develop, new learning oopportunities, new trainings, opportunity to travel occasionally etc
cons: cons:poor management, culture of favouritism and nepotism prevail, employees are not valued, people resign because of poor management etc

pros: Interesting issues, smart and fun colleagues, great mission.
cons: High staff turnover and little interaction with executive level staff. Sink or swim mentality with little to no mentorship.

pros: Great mission, good reputation, great middle management folks.
cons: Too top heavy and poor executive leadership. Allocation of resources not fairly distributed.

pros: Great people, like a home away from home ! Learn so much information, willing to train you in every position
cons: No Cons, really a great place!

pros: Interesting and important mission; great location in DC; building amenities
cons: There is just so much going on that everything feels disconnected. There is no sense of continuity in mission and the actual work.

review_title: An exciting and dynamic company working for the greater good
pros: I loved interning here! The people were great - friendly, smart, and definitely go-getters.
cons: Senior management seemed somewhat unapproachable.

pros: Awesome office at DC headquarters, great benefits, amazing global mission
cons: government policy funding and global political climate present strong challenges in this day and age.

pros: Great people, exciting work, clear mission

pros: Great benefits and salary package
cons: Extremely Euro-centric and American-centric, poor strategy, lack of trust in organisational environment, the list goes on...

pros: Exciting policy area, high profile campaigns.
cons: No concept of work-life balance; several big egos dominate, verging on harassment at times; the organisation sometimes struggles to retain credibility on issues of substance. Very stingy benefits package.

pros: Hip, energetic, well-funded, desire to do advocacy differently
